ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A thorough development that leads the Godel's Incompleteness theorem.
Computation theory and Godels Incompleteness Theorem
Definitions of computability (Turing Computable, Abacus Computable, Recursive Functions), Church's thesis, the halting problem, diagonalization, Gdel's incompleteness theorems.
I developed an understanding of logical systems and proof-based problem solving.
Godel's Incompleteness Theorem, relationship between computability and logic (recursive functions and turing machines)

Historical context on the developments in logic and the foundations of mathematics. Technical details on Gdel's incompleteness proofs. Different notions of computability like Turing machines, recursive functions

I learned more about Turing machines, abacus machines, recursive functions, and their equivalence. I also learned about Gdel's incompleteness theorems and a few other interesting topics relating to computability and logic. I got deeper insight into math and computation, which was really cool.
I learned a lot about the theory behind computation.
An intro to computability and logic

Knowledge: All kinds of theories and logical deductions behind breakthroughs regarding Computability and Logic. 
Skills: Deductive skills
Insights: the power and limit of computability and first-order logic

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Prof. Shin is an amazing lecturer. I feel that the course gets significantly harder towards the later half. The oral exam and the final pset are very difficult.
In general, I like the way this course is delivered. It would be somewhat better if the details of certain proofs are emphasized.

Strenghts: Course is well-designed; professor is enthusiastic about the material and teaching; lecture notes were great; Prof. Shin is the heart of the class; a good Hu credit for CS or MATH majors that don't wan't to take an usual Hu course.
Weaknesses: Lectures are long and most people weren't engaged (e.g. working on other psets).
Grading felt kind of arbitrary at times; the class was really interesting but it was impossible to know what reason you'd be scored down on assignments.
Professor Shin is a fantastic teacher, and her oral exams are a great way for students to know if they truly understand the material.

Strengths: Sun-Joo is a warm and charismatic lecturer who cares about the class and her students. Her handouts are detailed and makes it easy to follow along. Course material is super interesting.
Weaknesses: some lectures are student presentations of varying quality. If you want to actually learn the stuff the student groups talk about, read the textbook instead.

The content and the professor are fantastic. I'm so glad I took the course. I also think the pacing is a bit uneven. The week before the oral exam, the week of the final exam, and the week of the presentation are pretty intense. The rest of it is pretty chill.
The course in on a very niche subject so there are not that many materials online but the professor does a good job at providing the necessary materials in class.
Sun-Joo was an engaging teacher who explains content clearly.

Strengths: Interesting and fun lectures, problem sets, exams, and presentations.
Weakness: The preparatory materials for oral test could be richer, especially for the one uncovered during classes. Maybe there could be some practice exercises given before the actual oral test.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, definitely.

For those of you who are interested in proof-based course, I would definitely recommend this course since it's rather intellectually challenging. Meanwhile, you get to know a series of interesting theoretical concepts in the field of CS.
Sure. Material is interesting, professor is enthusiastic, and it's a great Humanities credit for STEM
Yes, if you're interested in learning how Gdel's incompleteness theorem works or in the concept of computability and its philosophical implications.
Yes!

Yes! If you're interested in the foundations of math or formal systems generally, this class is essential. If you have a math background this class will not be difficult, and the material is very interesting with a great lecturer. Workload is also pretty low, with the exception of preparing for the oral exam/if you're doing a presentation.

Yes if youre interested in the material, want a lower-workload credit, and are prepared to take a risk with your grade. Prof. Shin is a good teacher and really nice overall, although her exams (written and oral) can become exercises in reading her mind in a way that nobody would expect from a definition-theorem-proof kind of class.

Yes!\ The handouts for the course are well organized. The textbook is also useful and helpful. BE AWARE that the oral exam and the final are both quite time-intensive. The problem sets are more relaxed, and there are not too many of them. The content is also really cool. I'll admit -- I don't quite understand all of the technical details of the last two lectures of content, but I thought the class overall was really interesting. Some background in math or the prerequisites for the course is probably a good idea.

I would recommend this course to anyone with a solid proof background. If you have not been exposed to the theory of computability before, it may be a bit confusing at times. But if you have a strong proof background and are willing to put in the work, it will be a good class.
Yes, though I would like to see more OH/discussion sections.
Yes. This is such a fun class. The course materials are VERY engaging and the assessments were organized in a very fun and intriguing way.
